title: 114_hr5786
content: The Act titled "Community Protection and Preparedness Act of 2016" includes a provision for the establishment of a Rail Spill Preparedness Fund. The "Community Protection and Preparedness Act of 2016" includes the establishment of a Rail Spill Preparedness Fund, which creates a Rail Account in the Oil Spill Liability Trust Fund. A fee of $1,500 is imposed annually on certain railroad tank cars transporting Class 3 flammable liquids that do not meet specified safety regulations. The fee imposed on tank cars transporting Class 3 flammable liquids must be paid regardless of train composition or phase-out schedule. Railroad carriers transporting Class 3 flammable liquids are exempt from this fee. The Secretary will establish procedures for fee collection using government entities and may reimburse them for their services. Amounts equivalent to the fees collected will be deposited accordingly. Amounts collected as fees for transporting Class 3 flammable liquids by rail will be deposited into the Rail Account. These funds can be used by the Secretary for removal and remediation costs, as well as making grants to States and Indian tribes for emergency planning related to such incidents. The Secretary can use funds collected from fees for transporting Class 3 flammable liquids by rail for various purposes, including developing and training regional hazardous material emergency response teams, training public sector employees to respond to incidents, and implementing other safety measures in consultation with States and Indian tribes. The Secretary can use funds collected from fees for transporting Class 3 flammable liquids by rail for various purposes, including developing and training regional hazardous material emergency response teams, training public sector employees to respond to incidents, and implementing safety measures in consultation with States and Indian tribes. Grants under subsection (f) must ensure that emergency responders have the ability to protect nearby persons, property, and the environment from accidents involving hazardous materials, including Class 3 flammable liquids transported by rail. The section discusses the transportation of Class 3 flammable liquids by rail and clarifies that it does not affect compliance with federal or state laws. It also provides definitions for Class 3 flammable liquid and railroad carrier. Additionally, a conforming amendment is made to the analysis for chapter 51 of title 49, United States Code. SEC. 3. INCREASED INSPECTIONS OF CERTAIN RAIL TRACK. The section discusses the transportation of Class 3 flammable liquids by rail and clarifies that it does not affect compliance with federal or state laws. It also provides definitions for Class 3 flammable liquid and railroad carrier. Additionally, a conforming amendment is made to the analysis for chapter 51 of title 49, United States Code. The Secretary of Transportation must issue regulations within 9 months for Class I railroad carriers to inspect track where accidents involving flammable liquids or toxic materials could impact high consequence areas. Inspections must be done on foot and periodically using a gage restraint measurement system. Any deviations found must be remedied according to regulations. The Secretary of Transportation must issue regulations for Class I railroad carriers to inspect track near high consequence areas where accidents involving flammable liquids or toxic materials could occur. Other railroad carriers may also be required to inspect tracks based on risk factors. The regulations require Class I railroad carriers to inspect track near high consequence areas, which include high population areas, other populated areas, and unusually sensitive areas like drinking water or ecological resource areas. The term "material poisonous or toxic by inhalation" is defined in section 171.8 of title 49, Code of Federal Regulations. Other definitions in section 20102 of title 49, United States Code, also apply to this section. SEC. 4. TRACK SAFETY SPECIALISTS. Appropriation of funds for hiring 2 additional track safety specialists per region by the Administrator of the Federal Railroad Administration.
